    1 Regression

    1.1 Linear models

    1. linear model: coeffiecients β\betaβ are linear.

    1.1.2 Simple linear regression(SLR)

    y=β0+β1x+ϵi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=β0​+β1​x+ϵi​

    where

    • β0 population intercept ,β1 population slope \beta_0\text{ population intercept },\beta_1 \text{ population slope }β0​ population intercept ,β1​ population slope  are fixed but unknown. Estimated by b0 and b1b_0\text{ and } b_1b0​ and b1​ (whether using maximum likelihood or OLS, same result). β1\beta_1β1​ means the amount of change in E(y)E(y)E(y) when one unit change in x.
    • (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​) is a pair of data, plug in the formula: yi=β0+β1xi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0+\beta_1x_i+\epsilon_iyi​=β0​+β1​xi​+ϵi​ . The only variable in this formula is ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​.
    • ϵ\epsilonϵ is the model error, which follows the normal theory ϵi∼N(0,σ2)\epsilon_i \sim N(0,\sigma^2)ϵi​∼N(0,σ2).

      • It is iid(independent identically distributed). cov(ϵi,ϵj)=0,for i≠jcov(\epsilon_i,\epsilon_j)=0, \text{for i} \neq jcov(ϵi​,ϵj​)=0,for i=j.

      • Homogeneous variance assumption var(ϵi)=σ2var(\epsilon_i)=\sigma^2var(ϵi​)=σ2. (note: the unbiased estimator of σ\sigmaσ is sss)

        s2=1n−2∑i=1n(yi−yi^)2 s^2=\dfrac{1}{n-2}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\hat{y_i})^2 s2=n−21​i=1∑n​(yi​−yi​^​)2

        Some inferences:

    1. E(a)=aE(a)=aE(a)=a. E(ϵi)=0E(\epsilon_i)=0E(ϵi​)=0

      E(yi)=E(β0+β1+ϵi)=E(β0+β1xi)+E(ϵi)=β0+β1xi E(y_i)=E(\beta_0+\beta_1+\epsilon_i)=E(\beta_0+\beta_1x_i)+E(\epsilon_i)=\beta_0+\beta_1x_i E(yi​)=E(β0​+β1​+ϵi​)=E(β0​+β1​xi​)+E(ϵi​)=β0​+β1​xi​

    2. var(a)=0var(a)=0var(a)=0

      var(yi)=var(β0+β1+ϵi)=var(β0+β1xi)+var(ϵi)=σ2 var(y_i)=var(\beta_0+\beta_1+\epsilon_i)=var(\beta_0+\beta_1x_i)+var(\epsilon_i)=\sigma^2 var(yi​)=var(β0​+β1​+ϵi​)=var(β0​+β1​xi​)+var(ϵi​)=σ2

    1.1.3 Multiple linear regression (MLR)

    y^=Xβ^+ϵ^ \hat{y}=X\hat{\beta}+\hat{\epsilon} y^​=Xβ^​+ϵ^

    1.1.4 Ordinary least squares (OLS)

    1. A method to estimate unknown parasβ\betaβ. in a linear regression model.
    2. It can be used in SLR & MLR (>1 regressor).
    In SLR, 2 paras β0,β1\beta_0, \beta_1β0​,β1​, and their estimators are b0,b1b_0, b_1b0​,b1​. Use OLS:

    minJ(b0,b1)=minSSE=min∑i=1n[yi−yi^]2=min∑i=1n[yi−b0−b1xi]2 min J(b_0, b_1) = min SSE=min\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[y_i - \hat{y_i}]^2=min\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[y_i - b_0 -b_1x_i]^2 minJ(b0​,b1​)=minSSE=mini=1∑n​[yi​−yi​^​]2=mini=1∑n​[yi​−b0​−b1​xi​]2

    Use partial derivatives, tl.hen get 2 estimators:

    b0=yˉ−b1xˉ b_0 = \bar{y} - b_1\bar{x} b0​=yˉ​−b1​xˉ

    b1=nxˉyˉ−∑i=1nxiyinxˉ2−∑i=1nxi2=∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)yi∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)2=∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)2=SxySxx b_1=\dfrac{n\bar{x}\bar{y}-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_iy_i}{n\bar{x}^2-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_i^2} =\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})y_i}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} =\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} =\dfrac{S_\text{xy}}{S_\text{xx}} b1​=nxˉ2−i=1∑n​xi2​nxˉyˉ​−i=1∑n​xi​yi​​=i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)2i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)yi​​=i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)2i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​)​=Sxx​Sxy​​

    Because

    E(b0)=β0 E(b_0)=\beta_0 E(b0​)=β0​

    E(b1)=β1 E(b_1)=\beta_1 E(b1​)=β1​

    b0,b1b_0, b_1b0​,b1​ are unbiased estimators.

    var(b1)=σ2∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)2 var(b_1)= \dfrac{\sigma^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} var(b1​)=i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)2σ2​

    var(b0)=σ2(1n+xˉ2∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)2) var(b_0)=\sigma^2(\dfrac{1}{n}+\dfrac{\bar{x}^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2}) var(b0​)=σ2(n1​+i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)2xˉ2​)

    cov(b0,b1)=−xˉσ2Sxx cov(b_0,b_1) = -\dfrac{\bar{x}\sigma^2}{S_\text{xx}} cov(b0​,b1​)=−Sxx​xˉσ2​

    1.1.5 Analysis of variance (ANOVA)

    1. partition of digree of freedom for SLR. equation: y=β0+β1xy = \beta_0 + \beta_1xy=β0​+β1​x
      • k = 2 for(β0,β1\beta_0,\beta_1β0​,β1​)
      • n sample size

    ![[df.png]]

    1. Regression hypothesis

      H0:β1=0 H_0: \beta_1=0 H0​:β1​=0

      H1:β1≠0 H_1: \beta_1\neq0 H1​:β1​=0

      • H0 No regression relationship exists.H_0 \text{ No regression relationship exists.}H0​ No regression relationship exists.

      • H1 Regression analyasis exists.H_1 \text{ Regression analyasis exists.}H1​ Regression analyasis exists. Then do F-test: test for the entire regression. Is the reg statistically significant?

        Fk-1, n-k=MSRMSE=SSRk−1SSEn−k F_\text{k-1, n-k}=\dfrac{MSR}{MSE}=\dfrac{\frac{SSR}{k-1}}{\frac{SSE}{n-k}} Fk-1, n-k​=MSEMSR​=n−kSSE​k−1SSR​​

        where

      • k-1: df for reg

      • n-k: df for error Conclusion: Reject H0H_0H0​ if FCALC>FCVF_\text{CALC}>F_\text{CV}FCALC​>FCV​ . Regression analysis exists. Note: F value can be used for ranking the importance of features. The bigger the F for a feature, the bigger the SSR, in favor of H1H_1H1​.

    2. Hypothesis for β1\beta_1β1​

      H0:β1=0 H_0: \beta_1=0 H0​:β1​=0

      H1:β1≠0 H_1: \beta_1\neq0 H1​:β1​=0

      • H0 x has no impact on y.E(y)=β0H_0 \text{ x has no impact on y.} E(y)=\beta_0H0​ x has no impact on y.E(y)=β0​t-test is a test for only β1\beta_1β1​. Is there an evidence that x contributes information in the prediction of y?

        tn-k=b1MSE∑(x−xˉ)2 t_\text{n-k}=\dfrac{b_1}{\frac{\sqrt{MSE}}{\sqrt{\sum(x-\bar{x})^2}}} tn-k​=∑(x−xˉ)2​MSE​​b1​​

        Conclusion: Reject H0H_0H0​ if tCALC>tCVt_\text{CALC}>t_\text{CV}tCALC​>tCV​. x has impact on y.

    3. R2R^2R2 coefficient of determinate

      R2=SSRSST=∑i=1n(yi^−yˉ)2∑i=1n(yi−yˉ)2=1−SSESST R^2=\dfrac{SSR}{SST}=\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(\hat{y_i}-\bar{y})^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\bar{y}) ^2}=1-\dfrac{SSE}{SST} R2=SSTSSR​=i=1∑n​(yi​−yˉ​)2i=1∑n​(yi​^​−yˉ​)2​=1−SSTSSE​

      • 0<R2<10<R^2<10<R2<1
      • R2R^2R2 means the proportion of variation in the response data that is explained by the model.
      • R2R^2R2 on its own cannot tell you anything about causation. (causaion means that a change in one variable causes a change in another variable. correlation: there is a statistical association between variables)

    1.2 Generalized linear models (GLM)

    The differences between linear models and GLM. Standard linear model:

    • systematic component:

      y=β0+β1x+ϵi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=β0​+β1​x+ϵi​

    • Link function is one. μi=xiTβ\mu_i=x_i^T\betaμi​=xiT​β.
    • Random component: normal distribution yi∼N(μi,σ2)y_i \sim N(\mu_i,\sigma^2)yi​∼N(μi​,σ2) residuals are normally distributed.
    • Estimators: least squares or maximum likelihood will give the same result Not all situation can be considered as a normal distribution, large error.

    GLM:

    • systematic component:

      y=β0+β1x+ϵi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=β0​+β1​x+ϵi​

    • Link function is a function that delinearize the mathematical relationship between the predictors and the outcome. g(μi)=xiTβg(\mu_i)=x_i^T\betag(μi​)=xiT​β . The link function transforms the prediction part, everything except for the ϵ.\epsilon.ϵ. You need to decide this when doing analysis.

    • Random component: Residuals ars not normal, it might be comes from a poisson, a binomial, a gamma.

    • have to use maximum likelihood

      ![[Pasted image 20240803223049.png]] [1] Types of GLM.

    two tpyes of varia: binomial. skewed, positive discrete distribution: poisson. # times you go to a doctor. skewed, positive continuous dist: gamma

    2 Time series

    2.1 Time series data

    1. assumption: observations at a certain point depend on previous observations in time. decomposition: Time series = signal(forecasts extraplolate signal portion of model; trend/cycle and seasonal) +noise (confidence intervals account for uncertainty; error/remainder/irregular)
      • trend: classical: MA, morden way:
      • LOESS locally estimated scatterplot smoothing:non-parametric regression method that combines multiple regression models in a k-nearest-neighbor-based meta-model. This technique is used to fit a smooth curve through points in a scatterplot, especially when dealing with noisy data. Steps:
        • Choose a point of interest.
        • Identify the neighborhood around this point (based on the span).
        • Fit a weighted least squares regression to the points in the neighborhood.
        • Predict the value at the point of interest using the local regression model.
        • Repeat the process for all points in the dataset.
    import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from statsmodels.nonparametric.smoothers_lowess import lowess

# Example data
np.random.seed(0)
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x) + np.random.normal(0, 0.5, 100)

# Apply LOESS
smoothed = lowess(y, x, frac=0.2)  # frac is the span

# Plotting
plt.scatter(x, y, label='Data')
plt.plot(smoothed[:, 0], smoothed[:, 1], color='red', label='LOESS Smoothed')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

    2.2 Models for time series

    ![[Pasted image 20240805144951.png]] [4]

    1. Exponential smoothing models Apply a weighting scheme that decreases exponentially the further back in time we go. The larger the theta, the more recent observation is emphasized.

      Y^t+1=θYt+θ(1−θ)Yt-1+θ(1−θ)2Yt-2+θ(1−θ)3Yt-3+... \hat{Y}_\text{t+1}=\theta Y_t+\theta(1-\theta)Y_\text{t-1}+\theta(1-\theta)^2Y_\text{t-2}+\theta(1-\theta)^3Y_ \text{t-3}+... Y^t+1​=θYt​+θ(1−θ)Yt-1​+θ(1−θ)2Yt-2​+θ(1−θ)3Yt-3​+...

      0≤θ≤1 0\le\theta\le1 0≤θ≤1

      Simplify it, its prediction is like a horizontal line. So add trend and season terms in it. Holt winters exponential smoothing forecast:

      Y^t+k=Lt+kTt+St-p+k \hat{Y}_\text{t+k}=L_t+kT_t+S_\text{t-p+k} Y^t+k​=Lt​+kTt​+St-p+k​

      Lt=θYt+(1−θ)Lt-1 L_t=\theta Y_t + (1-\theta)L_\text{t-1} Lt​=θYt​+(1−θ)Lt-1​

      Tt=γ(Lt−Lt-1)+(1−γ)Tt-1 T_t=\gamma(L_t-L_\text{t-1})+(1-\gamma)T_\text{t-1} Tt​=γ(Lt​−Lt-1​)+(1−γ)Tt-1​

      St=δ(Yt−Lt)+(1−δ)St-p S_t=\delta(Y_t-L_t)+(1-\delta)S_\text{t-p} St​=δ(Yt​−Lt​)+(1−δ)St-p​

    2. consistency of distribution: can't have independece, but still want some consistency. Distribution depends only on difference in time, not location in time. same width(any size) of time, same distribution-strong stationarity. mean, var, autocorrelation depends only on difference in time-weak stationarity. Strong stationarity does not imply the weak one. Weak needs finite variance, strong does not.

    3. weak stationarity helps build stationary classes of models: MA...ARIMA not sationary: no consistent mean and var. 4.1 shifts in mean(not stationary): ![[Pasted image 20240804145903.png]] [4] common solution: differencing:

      • trend: look at the difference between the current point and previous one Yt−Yt-1Y_t-Y_\text{t-1}Yt​−Yt-1​
      • season: look at the difference between the current point and the same point in the previous season Yt−Yt-SY_t-Y_\text{t-S}Yt​−Yt-S​ 4.2 shifts in variance:
      • ignore when most models only model the mean
      • model the lack of consistency in var: ARCH/GARCH

    4. autoregressive models

      • forecast a series based on the past values in the series-lagsAR(1)

        Yt=ω+ϕYt-1+et Y_t = \omega + \phi Y_\text{t-1}+e_t Yt​=ω+ϕYt-1​+et​

        target YtY_tYt​ , Lagged Target Yt-1Y_\text{t-1}Yt-1​, ete_tet​ error.

      The recursion in time goes back until the beginngn of the series-long memory models. if ∣ϕ∣<1|\phi|<1∣ϕ∣<1 shocks happens long ago has little effect at the present.

      You can also has n lags AR(n).

    5. Moving average model. Forecast a series based solely on the past errors-error lags. short memory models

      Yt=ω+θet-1+et Y_t = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-1} + e_t Yt​=ω+θet-1​+et​

    ![[Pasted image 20240804224532.png]]

    MA(n)

    Yt-1=ω+θet-2+et-1 Y_\text{t-1} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-2} + e_\text{t-1} Yt-1​=ω+θet-2​+et-1​

    Yt=ω+θet-1+et Y_\text{t} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-1} + e_\text{t} Yt​=ω+θet-1​+et​

    Yt+1=ω+θet+et+1 Y_\text{t+1} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t} + e_\text{t+1} Yt+1​=ω+θet​+et+1​

    No more et-1e_\text{t-1}et-1​

    1. ARIMA

      1. ARIMA first, make your data stationary (typically done throug differencing). Distribution depends only on difference in time. AR, integrated, MA.

        Yt=ω+ϕ1Yt-1+...+ϕpYt-p+θ1et-1+...+θqet-q+et Y_t=\omega+\phi_1Y_\text{t-1}+...+\phi_pY_\text{t-p}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+...+\theta_qe_\text{t-q}+e_t Yt​=ω+ϕ1​Yt-1​+...+ϕp​Yt-p​+θ1​et-1​+...+θq​et-q​+et​

        Deciding how many p's and q's. 2 techniques:

        • Plotting patterns in correlation
        • Automatic selection techniques: MINIC, SCAN, ESACF

        ARIMA(d,p,q)=ARIMA(#ARterms, # first differences, # Aterms)

        ARIMA(1,1,1) ARIMA(1,1,1) ARIMA(1,1,1)

        Yt−Yt-1=Wt Y_t-Y_\text{t-1}=W_t Yt​−Yt-1​=Wt​

        Wt=ω+ϕ1Wt-1+θ1et-1+et W_t=\omega+\phi_1W_\text{t-1}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+e_t Wt​=ω+ϕ1​Wt-1​+θ1​et-1​+et​

      2. seasonal ARIMA: when data are not stationary. ARIMA(p,d,q)(P,D,Q)s

        • P: # seasonal AR terms
        • D: # seasonal differences
        • Q: # seasonal MA terms
        • s: length of season

        ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)12 ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)_\text{12} ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)12​

        Yt−Yt-12=Wt Y_t-Y_\text{t-12}=W_t Yt​−Yt-12​=Wt​

        Wt=ω+ϕ1Wt-1+ϕ2Wt-12+ϕ3Wt-24+θ1et-1+et W_t=\omega+\phi_1W_\text{t-1}+\phi_2W_\text{t-12}+\phi_3W_\text{t-24}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+e_t Wt​=ω+ϕ1​Wt-1​+ϕ2​Wt-12​+ϕ3​Wt-24​+θ1​et-1​+et​

    2. Neural network time series models input: # Number of autoregressive lags(AR lags): explore with correlation plots or aotomatic selection tecniques. seasonal data: typically include all lags up through one season unless correlation plots say you only need specific ones. STILL WANT TO MAKE DATA STATIONARY FIRST.

    3. Prophet model Time series = signal(forecasts extraplolate signal portion of model; trend/cycle, seasonal, holiday) +noise (confidence intervals account for uncertainty; error/remainder/irregular)

      1. trend lines with knots, logorithm trend...
      2. seasonal: fourier transformation
      3. holiday-point(pulse) intervention

    4. Vector autoregressive (VAR) model:

      1. model multiple time series at one time.
      2. multivariate regression is not multiple regression
      3. trying to predict multiple target variable at the same time
      4. when estimating 1 target variable, common: ARMA>AR
      5. when .... multiple ... , common: VAR > VARMA ![[Pasted image 20240805151510.png]] [5]

    5. Bayesian autoregressive models

      Yt=α0+α1Yt-1+...+αpYt-q+et Y_t=\alpha_0+\alpha_1Y_\text{t-1}+...+\alpha_pY_\text{t-q}+e_t Yt​=α0​+α1​Yt-1​+...+αp​Yt-q​+et​

    6. ARCH, GARCH

      1. unconditional variance

        Var(x)=σ2=1n−1∑i=1n(xi−xˉ2)=E(x−E(x))2 Var(x)=\sigma^2=\dfrac{1}{n-1}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x}^2)=E(x-E(x))^2 Var(x)=σ2=n−11​i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ2)=E(x−E(x))2

      2. conditional variance: the measure of uncertainty about a variable given a set of information Heteroscedasticity-variance depends on external factors.(variance are changing)

        Var(x∣I)=σcond2=E(x−E(x∣I))2 Var(x|I)=\sigma_\text{cond}^2=E(x-E(x|I))^2 Var(x∣I)=σcond2​=E(x−E(x∣I))2

        In cross-sectional data, heteroscedasticity: avoid In time series data especially in finance: we desire to model it. 建模return 更有规律。

      3. Autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity. Trying to account for time dependency and "clustering" of volatility. Volatility tommorow: σt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2σt+12​ Actual today: rt2r_t^2rt2​

        σt+12=α0+α1rt2 \sigma_\text{t+1}^2=\alpha_0+\alpha_1r_t^2 σt+12​=α0​+α1​rt2​

        why? Use squared returns to estimate a daily volatility:

        σt2=1t∑i=1t(rt−rˉ)2=1t∑i=1t(rt−0)2=11∑i=1t(rt)2=rt2 \sigma_\text{t}^2=\frac{1}{t}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t-\bar{r})^2 =\frac{1}{t}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t-0)^2 =\frac{1}{1}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t)^2 =r_t^2 σt2​=t1​i=1∑t​(rt​−rˉ)2=t1​i=1∑t​(rt​−0)2=11​i=1∑t​(rt​)2=rt2​

        • volatility tomorrow: σt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2σt+12​
        • actual today: α1rt2\alpha_1r_t^2α1​rt2​ ARCH(n) uses multiple lags in the past to model the volatility.

      4. generalized ARCH (GARCH).

        σt+12=α0+α1rt2+β1σt^2 \sigma_\text{t+1}^2=\alpha_0+\alpha_1r_t^2+\beta_1\hat{\sigma_t}^2 σt+12​=α0​+α1​rt2​+β1​σt​^​2

        • volatility tomorrow: σt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2σt+12​ Real world data typically needs one of each:
        • actual today: α1rt2\alpha_1r_t^2α1​rt2​
        • forecasted today:β1σt^2\beta_1\hat{\sigma_t}^2β1​σt​^​2

    7. ECM Anerror correction model(ECM) belongs to a category of multiple time seriesmodels most commonly used for data where the underlying variables have a long-run common stochastic trend, also known as cointegration.[3]

    2.3 Model evaluation

    1. Prediction MAPE. mean absolute percentage error

      MAPE=1n∑t=1n∣Yt−Yt^Yt∣ MAPE=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{n}|\dfrac{Y_t-\hat{Y_t}}{Y_t}| MAPE=n1​t=1∑n​∣Yt​Yt​−Yt​^​​∣

      sMAPE. symmetric MAPE

      sMAPE=1n∑t=1n∣Yt−Yt^∣(∣Yt∣+∣Yt^∣) sMAPE=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{n}\dfrac{|Y_t-\hat{Y_t}|}{(|Y_t|+|\hat{Y_t}|)} sMAPE=n1​t=1∑n​(∣Yt​∣+∣Yt​^​∣)∣Yt​−Yt​^​∣​

    2. validation: rolling hold-out samples: 连续的按顺序逐步下扩张自己的训练集，测试集长度不变紧跟训练集。一次完成后，记录误差，模型基于此次训练集更新。然后继续向下扩张特定数量的训练集。

    3 Nonparametric Regression

    Splines, Kernel, Locally Weighted Regression Most of tools in classical statistics are parametrics, they rely on assumptions about the underlying distribution of the data being studied.Techniques like least squares regression (which assumes normally distributed residuals) are parametric.Non-parametric machine learning algorithms do not rely on assumptions about the shape of the underlying data to work.

    https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/density-plots-with-pandas-in-python/

    2. estimation
